We’re currently looking for C# and .NET developers. If you are an EU national with a university degree, relevant work experience and would like to work in an agile and multinational team, we’d love to receive your application by 17 January 2020 https://t.co/C53ivCjs8N #coding https://t.co/YJylMOPvWi

Are you a legal scholar researching topics related to the ECB’s tasks? We are awarding up to six scholarships for research papers in 2020. Find out more on our website and send us your application by 3 February 2020 https://t.co/2DehIUSEWF https://t.co/CJUh6yqde8
Benoît Cœuré: Technology will create new policy choices and options enabling central banks to continue acting within their mandates https://t.co/nZLf78riw8
Benoît Cœuré: If monetary policy remains a conversation between central banks and financial markets, we shouldn’t be surprised if people don’t trust us https://t.co/nZLf78riw8

Benoît Cœuré: The ECB could communicate the range of inflation outcomes that can be considered acceptable in normal times. The 2% inflation objective needs to remain the clear nominal anchor for expectations and actions https://t.co/nZLf78riw8
Benoît Cœuré: The ECB should clarify that it aims to deliver inflation of 2% over the medium term and do more to communicate this target to the broader public https://t.co/nZLf78riw8
Benoît Cœuré: Central banks have one key strength: agility. They have always been able to reinvent themselves, to innovate and overcome even severe impediments to transmission https://t.co/nZLf78riw8

In his final speech as a member of the Executive Board, Benoît Cœuré reflects on the success central banks have achieved in recent years and looks ahead to the future of monetary policy. Read his full speech here https://t.co/nZLf78riw8 https://t.co/CIHNa7BhLW

How can we increase people’s trust in the banking system? In yesterday’s #ECBYouthDialogue at @SapienzaRoma, Supervisory Board Chair Andrea Enria explained that banking supervision is key to increasing credibility.
Here’s what Flavio, one of the students at the event, thought. https://t.co/O0MLXb1DUT

Read our paper on exploring anonymity in central bank digital currencies https://t.co/DCJerLdJI8

Our latest research shows that it is possible to build a simplified payment system for central bank digital currencies. Such a system would safeguard users’ privacy for low-value transactions while ensuring that higher-value transfers are subject to anti-money laundering checks.

https://t.co/AUKr679Fpl
Projection charts and tables 
https://t.co/CogeDVsYmc https://t.co/HwAqC1S1q6
Introductory statement to the press conference https://t.co/XOcAua92cL
Lagarde: To think that the ESM review is targeted against a particular country is completely misguided
Lagarde: In our strategic review we will take up climate change and see where and how we can participate in the particular endeavor
Lagarde: I would like to compliment Greece. I'm really delighted to see the progress and the recovery.
Lagarde: My personal conviction on the issue of stable coins is that we better be ahead of the curve. There is clearly demand out there that we have to respond to.
Lagarde: What gives us hope is the fact that the downside risks to the growth outlook are less pronounced
Lagarde: I don't see anything wrong with policy makers agreeing to make the efforts that they can to reach their respective goals
Lagarde: To me it is critically important that a central bank is independent and that its independence is respected and valued
Lagarde: Policy decisions that were made stand. And they were re-endorsed.

Lagarde: It would be very welcome to have other policies join monetary policy to support the reduction of slack and arrive at the growth potential - both in fiscal terms and in terms of structural reforms
Lagarde: We are very much aware of the side effects. We will continue to monitor the side effects and we might further develop that work.
Lagarde: The fourth quarter of 2022 is at 1.7% for the inflation projection. It is directionally good but is it the aim we pursue? No, indeed.
Lagarde: There is no preconceived landing zone at this point in time for the outcome of the strategic review
Lagarde: My plan is to start the strategic review in January and complete it by the end of 2020

Lagarde: Governments with fiscal space should be ready to act in an effective and timely manner. In countries where public debt is high, governments need to pursue prudent policies and meet structural balance targets
Lagarde: In view of the weakened economic outlook, the Governing Council welcomes the Eurogroup’s call for differentiated fiscal responses and its readiness to coordinate

Lagarde: In order to reap the full benefits from our monetary policy measures, other policy areas must contribute more decisively to raising the longer-term growth potential, supporting aggregate demand at the current juncture and reducing vulnerabilities

Lagarde: A cross-check of the economic analysis with the signals coming from the monetary analysis confirmed an ample degree of monetary accommodation is still necessary for the continued robust convergence of inflation to levels that are below, but close to, 2%
Lagarde: The growth of loans to firms and households remained solid, benefiting from the continued pass-through of our accommodative monetary policy stance to bank lending rates
Lagarde introduces the GDP and inflation outlook for the euro area https://t.co/69TZRfj4IZ
Lagarde: Over the medium term, inflation is expected to increase, supported by our monetary policy measures, the ongoing economic expansion and solid wage growth
Lagarde: While labour cost pressures have strengthened amid tighter labour markets, the weaker growth momentum is delaying their pass-through to inflation
Lagarde: On the basis of current futures prices for oil, headline inflation is likely to rise somewhat in the coming months. Indicators of inflation expectations stand at low levels

Lagarde: The risks surrounding the euro area growth outlook, related to geopolitical factors, rising protectionism and vulnerabilities in emerging markets, remain tilted to the downside, but have become somewhat less pronounced

Lagarde: The Governing Council continues to stand ready to adjust all of its instruments, as appropriate, to ensure that inflation moves towards its aim in a sustained manner, in line with its commitment to symmetry
Lagarde: The Governing Council’s forward guidance will ensure that financial conditions adjust in accordance with changes to the inflation outlook

Lagarde: In the light of the subdued inflation outlook, the Governing Council reiterated the need for monetary policy to remain highly accommodative for a prolonged period of time to support underlying inflation pressures and headline inflation developments over the medium term

Lagarde: Easier borrowing conditions for firms and households will support the euro area expansion, the ongoing build-up of domestic price pressures and, thus, the robust convergence of inflation to our medium-term aim
Lagarde: In particular, easier borrowing conditions for firms and households are underpinning consumer spending and business investment

Lagarde: The comprehensive package of policy measures that the Governing Council decided in September provides substantial monetary stimulus, which ensures favourable financing conditions for all sectors of the economy

Lagarde: Incoming data point to continued muted inflation pressures and weak euro area growth dynamics, although there are some initial signs of stabilisation in the growth slowdown and of a mild increase in underlying inflation in line with previous expectations

Lagarde: We intend to continue reinvesting, in full, the principal payments from maturing securities purchased under the APP for an extended period of time past the date when we start raising the key ECB interest rates
Lagarde: We expect net purchases to run for as long as necessary to reinforce the accommodative impact of our policy rates, and to end shortly before we start raising the key ECB interest rates
Lagarde: … and until such convergence has been consistently reflected in underlying inflation dynamics (2/2)
